Carbon-based nanomaterials (CNMs) such as graphene and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have huge potential in environment and energy related applications. Although a wide range of synthesis methods has been developed to produce CNMs, green synthesis methods with either energy-saving reactions or inexpensive starting materials are gaining more attentions recently. It is evident from recent developments that converting low-valued waste materials into high-valued CNMs contributes towards sustainable materials processing and recycle technology. Objective of this review is to analyze green synthesis routes to prepare CNMs focusing on graphene and CNTs. This review starts with the identification of wastes that can be used as resources for producing CNMs followed by discussing various methods of CNTs and graphene synthesis. Finally, a summary of current status and future prospects of green synthesis methods are discussed.

1. Introduction
Waste materials ranging from household wastes to industrial residues, cause detrimental effects on environment and human health [1]. However, wastes can be exploited as utility resources to prepare value-added products [2]. One of the important techniques to achieve this objective is pyrolysis. Pyrolysis belongs to thermal decomposition, which is operated in air-free condition [3]. Besides generating gases, various liquid phases and solid char can be obtained by manipulating pyrolysis parameters, such as operating temperature and heating rate [3]. As one of the potential resources, waste plastics have been used as raw materials to produce gasoline, light oils [3] and steel [4] simply by pyrolyzing at elevated temperature. Another example of recycling is the conversion of biomass wastes into various valuable chemicals such as biofuels and alcohols [5]. In another work, Yunos et al. have used palm shell which is a kind of agriculture wastes to partially substitute metallurgical coke in steelmaking [6]. Apart from the waste plastics and biomass, automotive wastes such as glass have also been used as resource to prepare ferrosilicon alloys and silicon carbide nanoparticles [7]. Moreover, ceramics with high mechanical strength and inertness can also be prepared from wastes. For example, Yugeswaran et al. used arc plasma method to transform laboratory silica wastes into mullite, which is a well-known advanced ceramic with outstanding creep resistance and thermal shock resistance [8]. Similarly, glass and ceramics have been made from nuclear wastes by using arc plasma method [9]. As discussed above, recycling waste materials into high-valued products such as steels and ceramics are markedly feasible, which has inspired researchers to synthesis carbon-based nanomaterials (CNMs) from wastes resources for various potential applications. CNMs, such as graphene and carbon nanotubes (CNTs), have been materials of priority for research in nanotechnology. Graphene and CNTs with their robust mechanical, electronic, physical and chemical properties are playing increasingly significant roles in super-capacitors, transistors, transparent photo-electronic devices and sensors [10]. A variety of synthesis methods have been used to produce CNMs [11, 12]. Although CNMs with high quality can be produced through those conventional methods, one crucial challenge is to achieve environmental friendly productions in large scale with low cost [11, 12]. Synthesis of CNMs starting from wastes is likely to reduce the amount of solid wastes and lower the fabrication cost simultaneously. More importantly, using waste as resources is an encouraging step for recycling technology. Wastes with high carbon content, especially waste plastics, are considered as pronounced precursors for making CNMs. In this review we have given

2. Carbon nanotubes (CNTs)
There are two basic forms of CNTs, named as single-walled nanotubes (SWNTs) and multiwalled nanotubes (MWNTs) [13]. The structure of SWNTs is like a rolled-up graphene sheet, the unit of which is in hexagonal shape constituted by sp2 hybrid carbon atoms with bonding (in plane) and bonding (out of plane) [14]. When rolling followed different chiral
vector , varied SWNTs can be derived. Chiral vector is determined by integers and graphene
vectors, which can be calculated by equation =n +m [12,14]. Three main types of SWNTs constructions can be classified according to integer values (n, m). The first type is (n, 0), which is defined as zigzag structure and shows metallic properties; the second type is n=m, which is named as armchair structure and possesses semiconductor properties; the third type is n>m>0, which is called chiral structure and has semi-metal properties [13,15]. The influence brought by chirality is not limited on electronic properties, but also on other aspects, such as mechanical properties [15,16]. As for MWNTs, it consists of several co-axial SWNTs. Since those SWNTs can have same or varied chirality, MWNTs can own combined properties [12]. In general, the diameter of SWNTs is in the range of nanometer (nm), while the diameter of MWNTs is usually an order of magnitude higher [14]. The basic properties and related applications of CNTs are briefly clarified below. Mechanical properties: CNTs possess remarkable mechanical properties, such as stiffness, strength and toughness due to strong σ bonding [14]. The Young’s modulus of CNTs is over 1TPa, and its tensile strength is up to 100GPa [17,18]. These make CNTs a virtually dominate role in advanced structural applications, such as CNT-reinforced polymer composites [19]. Electrical properties: As aforementioned, CNTs can present semiconducting or metallic properties when their structures are altered [13]. Especially for metallic CNTs, its electrical conductivity can be orders of magnitudes higher than copper theoretically [20,21]. Besides superlative quantum effects and electronic properties, CNTs’ magnetic and lattice properties are premium [13]. Also, CNTs can well respond to strain through transforming from metallic status to insulating condition [14,20]. Thermal and optical properties: When temperature is over ambient temperature, the unique structure of CNTs offers ultimately high thermal conductivity and heat capacity [14]. The thermal properties are altered as temperature drops due to quantum confinement effects [14]. Taking advantages of these features, CNTs are better choices over conventional materials for

sections.heading: 2.2.1 Waste Plastics for CNTs synthesis:
sections.text:
CNTs synthesis methods from waste plastics were conducted in various reactor systems, such as quartz tube, autoclave, crucible and muffle furnace [27]. They share the same objective which is to break down the large solid polymer into small carbon precursors through pyrolysis [2]. Polyolefin (carbon content: around 85.7wt %) is a type of polymers originated from olefin monomer (CnH2n), which accounts for the majority of waste plastics [28]. Two prototypes of waste polyolefins named polypropylene (PP) and polyethylene (PE) have been commonly used for green synthesis methods for carbon materials [28]. Plastics incorporated with other elements besides C and H, such as polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) and polyethylene terephthalate (PET), were also successfully used for CNTs synthesis.
Fig. 2 CVD setup for CNTs synthesis in Mishra et al. work (Reprinted with permission from ref. 29)
Mishra et al. used CVD setup to synthesize CNTs from waste PP (see Figure 2) [29]. PP (~10g) was placed on one quartz boat, while another boat loaded catalyst Ni (~1mg) inside the quartz tubes as shown in Figure 2 [29]. Electrical heating furnace provided heat treatment (600-800oC) to the tube which was accompanied with H2 (10sccm) and Ar (90sccm) flowing into [29]. When temperature rose over 400℃, PP started decomposing into carbon atoms and subsequently dissolved into the hot area of Ni. While in cold area of Ni, precipitated carbon atoms served as nucleating sites for CNTs growth [29]. Temperature gradient between hot and cold areas is critical for CNTs growth mostly because it can be seemed as a driving force for carbon atoms diffusion in this process [29]. In order to forbid catalyst poisoning and amorphous carbon formation, the concentration of carbon in hot area should be higher than that in cold area [29]. Ultimately, high quality MWNTs (yield up to 20 wt%) were obtained. Likewise, Gong et al. developed a newly synthesis method starting with waste PP catalyzed by activated carbon (AC) and Ni2O3 in quartz tube reactor. They named this synthesis

Bajad et al. achieved considerable yield (~45.8%) of MWNTs from PP waste catalyzed by Ni/Mo/MgO (mole ration: 4/0.2/1) [33]. After adding these catalysis powders, PP was placed in a lid-covered Si crucible and heated in electrical muffle furnace to 800℃ [33]. It was borne out that higher Mo content was helpful for the formation of CNTs with larger diameter, whereas the lower Mo content led to the production of CNTs with smaller diameter but higher yield [33].
Tang et al. demonstrated the synthesis of MWNTs from PP in an open reaction system [34]. Owing to the addition of organic modified clay (OMC), a tortuous path was developed in the top charred ceramic layer after combustion. So the leak of carbon-gaseous precursors can be retarded, meanwhile a mimic micro-autoclave was generated to offer interacted place for pyrolytic products and catalytic Ni particles [34]. After dehydrogenation and aromatization of pyrolytic products, MWNTs were produced [34]. The highest yield of MWNTs (~41.16 wt%) can be obtained when added 10 wt% OMC [34]. It was confirmed that this method was also applicable for other polymer materials [34].
Nath et al. derived CNTs with high yield (~54%) from PVA composite film [35]. First step was to dissolve PVA in deionized water with fly ash (FA) dispersed inside [36]. Next step was to cast the mixture of PVA/FA/deionized water in glassy-petri dishes. Once the mixture became dry, PVA composite film was obtained [37]. The pyrolysis process was conducted in a horizontal quartz tube filled with N2 atmosphere [35]. Once the temperature in hot section reached suitable range (~500℃), the sample was pushed from cold section into hot section by graphite feeder [36]. Sample was kept at hot section for nearly 10 min to complete pyrolysis, after which crucible was returned back to cold sections and CNTs were collected at ambient temperature [37]. The interfacial bonding between PVA and FA was suggested to giving essential effect on the formation of CNTs along FA surface [37]. Meanwhile FA served as catalyst to assist the cleavage of PVA chains, thus allowing carbon double-bonded building blocks integrated into sp2 conformation [37]. The final product (CNTs-FA mixture) is found to be used as promising fillers in composites to reinforce their mechanical performance [36]. Berkmans et al. proposed a catalysis-free synthesis of nano-channeled CNTs from waste PET [38]. sections.heading: 2.2.2 Waste vegetable and animal oil for CNTs synthesis:
sections.text:
Vegetable oils can be extracted from coconut, neem, turpentine, eucalyptus and palm, which
commonly possess considerable carbon content for fabricating highly pure (~90%) CNTs [39]. Among those, palm oil (C55H100O6) stands out in providing CNT with prominent quality. Because its low H content ensures diminished formation of amorphous carbon [39]. Suriani et al. produced vertical aligned CNTs (VACNTs) from waste cooking palm oil [40]. Float-catalytic CVD equipment made of two alumina tube furnaces was utilized and starting materials were filtered palm oil well mixed with ferrocene (5.33wt %) [40]. The mixture was placed in an alumina boat at the center of one tube furnace, meanwhile the cleaned silicon substrate was loaded at the center of another one [40]. After the latter tube was preheated to 750℃ in Ar atmosphere, the former tube was heated to 450℃ for 30min to allow waste palm

After successfully synthesizing VACNTs from waste cooking palm oil, Suriani et al. proceeded by using animal oil as raw materials [39]. Chicken fat was selected among animal oils, which is a common waste residue of chicken [39]. Moreover, it has abundant carbon component as well as low ratio of C/H like vegetable oil. At first, chicken oil was extracted by heating the chicken fat. Next step was adding ferrocene (5.33wt %) as catalysts. The mixture was subsequently put into the same CVD setup as what they used for palm oil [41]. Also, similar operating steps were done aside from the first furnace was heated to 470℃ for 60min [41]. Finally, VACNTs with remarkable crystallinity and purity (88.2%) were given [41].

sections.heading: 2.2.3 Industrial wastes for CNTs synthesis:
sections.text:
Besides using oil wastes, Suriani et al. conducted a synthesis of quasi-aligned CNTs starting from waste engine oil (WEO), which contains much higher carbon content than other oils [42]. Still, same CVD setup was applied but here 17.99wt% ferrocene was used and the temperature for precursor and synthesis were 500 and 750℃ respectively [42]. It was observed that oxygen content of WEO has a promotion effect on increasing the crystallinity of CNTs as the oxygen component can potentially offer hydroxyl radicals, which lay the foundation of stable sp2 structure in CNTs [42].
Oscar et al. collected red muds from the wastes generated during Bayer process of alumina fabrication as catalysts for MWNTs synthesis [43]. The considerable Fe content (Fe2O3, 20~60%) of red muds enables them to realize sufficient catalysis effects. The carbon precursor was ethylene, which was catalyzed by red muds in fluidized bed reactor at the temperature of 650℃ [43].
Quan et al. found that the printed circuit board (PCB) wastes can be exploited in CNTs synthesis [44]. At first, the authors decomposed PCB at 600℃ to extract pyrolysis oil. The oil was identified to contain high content of phenol and other aromatic species [44]. Followed step was converting the pyrolysis oil into resin by polymerizing with formaldehyde. After that, the resin was mixed with catalyst ferrocene and pyrolyzed (900℃) under N2 inert atmosphere [44]. Finally, CNTs with 338nm diameter and 86nm wall thickness were produced and the maximum yield was up to 56% [44].

3. Graphene
Graphene is referred as an atomic layer of graphite, which is also the basic unit for fullerenes and CNTs [50]. Its 2D crystal structure is constructed from two types of sp2 hybridized carbon atoms closely packing into honeycomb lattice by bonding, in which delocalized electrons presence due to orbitals of carbon atoms [51-54]. Whereas, it is so far beyond the definition as 2D graphene but rather as 3D thin graphite when the number of graphene layers exceeds ten [50,54]. Raman spectroscopy is commonly used to determine its number of layers [55]. In Raman spectrum of single layer graphene, there are three main peaks: D peak locates at ~1350 cm-1, the higher of which the more defects and disorders presence; G peak locates at ~1580 cm-1, which associates with bond stretching of sp2 carbon atoms and gives the information of crystallinity; G’ peak also called 2D peak locates at ~2700 cm -1, which is attributed to two phonons with contrast momentum near K points [55,56]. Number of layers can be roughly estimated based on intensity ratio of G and D peaks. If IG/I2D is around 0.5, it indicates single layer graphene is obtained [56]. of graphene are briefly discussed below. Optical properties: Owing to its 2D structure and zero band-gap, single layer graphene is nearly transparent (transmittance T≈97.7%). The transparency decreases with increasing number of layers [51]. Every one more layer results transmittance dropping 2.3% [57]. In addition, fast-moving carriers provide a rapid photo-response without applying high electrical field [52]. Because of these good optical features, graphene is likely to be applied in optoelectronic devices, such as sensors and transparent electrodes [52,53]. Mechanical properties: The mechanical properties of graphene are also extremely astonishing attributed to its ultra-strong covalent bonds and compacted structure. It has been manifested that graphene is the unprecedentedly strongest material in the world with Young’s modulus as high as 1TPa (nearly five times higher than that of steel 0.2TPa) [58]. The intrinsic strength of monolayer graphene was reported to be 130 GPa, which is currently the highest among all materials [58]. Nonetheless, the fracture toughness of graphene was found
to be ordinary which indicated by its critical stress intensity factor (~4 MPa√ ) [59]. Thanks to its strong properties and light density, investigations on graphene-based filler and composites are gearing up [52]. Electronic properties: The unique electronic structure imparts graphene pronounced superiorities in electronic respects. The tunable band gap offers its distinct features between semiconductor and metal. The effect of ambipolar electric field allows charge carriers to possess extremely high concentration (~1013cm-2) and extraordinarily rapid mobility (> 15,000cm2V-1s-1) [50,60]. Importantly, the mobility is nearly independent of temperature and can be further boosted to 100,000cm2V-1s-1 [50,61]. And the quantum Hall effect (QHE) presences even at ambient temperature [50,61]. Hence, graphene is emerged as an ideal choice for application of nano-sized transistors and electronics which need ballistic transport, massive current sustainability (>108 A/cm2), linear current-voltage features and giant in-plane electrical conductivity [60]. Thermal properties: Furthermore, graphene shows great thermal properties because of its robust covalent bonds. The thermal stability of graphene is prominent even under elevated temperature [50]. Its thermal conductivity is varied and determined by phonon transport, including diffusive conduction at elevated temperature and ballistic conduction at reduced temperature [52]. Thermal conductivity decreases with temperature rising once temperature is over 100K [52]. It is well-known that copper shows excellent thermal conductivity (400 W/mK), but the thermal conductivity of graphene (prepared by mechanically exfoliation) was

Chemical Vapor Deposition (CVD): In this method, a catalytic substrate is loaded in the quartz tube with inert gas (Ar/H2) introducing at a certain pressure for a period time to create reducing atmosphere and pre-heat the substrate. Once suitable temperature reaches, mixedgas precursor is injected into the tube to interact with catalytic substrate resulting a thin layer of graphene formed on the top of catalyst eventually [67,68]. Though there are many metal (catalytic) substrates for CVD graphene synthesis, such as Pt, Co, Ir and Ru, the most commonly used are Cu and Ni [67]. Compared with Ni, mono-layered graphene can be more easily formed on Cu substrate, due to their different growth mechanisms [69]. In Cu catalytic synthesis, since the carbon solubility in Cu is extremely low, carbon atoms decomposed from precursors arrange into graphene structure directly [68,69]. However, Ni with relatively high carbon solubility can dissolve large amounts of carbon atoms at elevated temperature and eject them out during cooling [69]. The large amounts of precipitated carbon atoms are likely to cause the formation of multilayer graphene. So, it is critical to employ appropriate cooling conditions to avoid ending up with multilayer graphene [69]. To date, CVD has been deemed to be a very effective method to provide graphene with not only high quality and yield, but also large surface area. The resulted graphene is desired for electronics or optical devices [67]. Si atoms are sublimated from SiC substrate at the temperature in the range of 1200 to 1800℃ and the remaining carbon abundant surface attributes to the formation of graphene films [70,71]. This method can produce graphene for electronic applications [63]. Drawbacks of this method are also obvious, such as expensive SiC as raw materials, massive energy consuming for applying high synthesis temperature. 3.2.2 Biomass wastes for graphene synthesis:
As products of plants photosynthesis, biomass wastes can be the by-products or residues from agricultural refuse, ligneous plants and waste water deposits [78]. The biomass wastes are not only valuable for sustainable energy resources, like bio-fuels, but also have potential to be used as carbon sources for fabrication of valuable CNMs [78,79]. For example, Sun et al. used coconut shell (a kind of biomass wastes) to produce porous graphene nanosheets [79]. In their method, the coconut shell (~3g) and ZnCl2 (~9g, activating agent) were mixed with FeCl3 solution (~50mL, 3M, catalyst precursor) [79]. Carbon precursor was collected after the evaporation (~80℃, 2hrs) and drying step (~100℃) of mixed solution. Following step was to heat the carbon precursor (~900℃, 1hr) in a tube furnace under N2 atmosphere [79] to obtain graphene nanosheets. Primo et al. used chitosan extracted from crustacean skin wastes for catalyst-free synthesis of N-doped graphene [80]. They prepared polysaccharide thin films by spin coating chitosan solution. These films were subsequently annealed (200℃ , 2hrs) in Ar atmosphere and pyrolysized (600~800℃) under oxygen-free condition [80]. The N content in chitosan was able to cause the doping effect in graphene. Akhavan et al. replaced costly HPG (highly pyrolytic graphite) with natural and industrial carbonaceous wastes to synthesize GO and rGO [82]. In the reported methods, raw materials wrapped in Al foil were burnt (400~500℃) in poor-oxygen condition for five days and milled into fine powders and heated (450℃) again for one day and dispersed in aqueous solution of FeCl3∙6H2O and HCl. The final graphitized product was used for GO synthesis by using modified Hummers method. Recently, Adolfsson et al. proposed a method using waste paper for graphene oxide quantum dots synthesis [83]. In their work, the abundant cellulose content collected from waste paper was converted into carbon nanospheres by subsequently hydrothermal (160℃) degradation in microwave equipment under the catalysis effect of H2SO4 [83]. The carbon nanospheres were transformed into graphene oxide quantum dots by sonication and heating in 70% HNO3 solution [83].
4. Conclusions
Green synthesis of materials has been investigated for many years in the past. Most of the experiments discussed in this review used wastes feedstock in milligram range to produce CNMs. These methods can also produce CNMs with a considerable yield with highest value of ~ 80%. Hence, it highly supports the prospection that productive and sustainable fabrication for CNMs and effective reduction for solid wastes can be realized when large scaled synthesis is achieved, for instance Wu et al. transformed 1ton waste glycerol into 2.8kg CNTs [49]. Compared with CNTs, the methods for green synthesis for graphene are relatively limited. The methodologies developed on green synthesis of CNTs can be extended to produce graphene with good quality. In general, plastic and biomass wastes have been the most popular resources for synthesis of CNTs and graphene. However, the reported results

suggested the CNMs produced from plastic are better in quality than CNMs produced from biomass. One possible reason for this can be the chemical composition of biomass is more complicated. The green synthesis methods developed so far need further modifications to scale up the productions on CNMs. It is extremely important to select appropriate waste materials as resources. Synthesis of CNMs from waste is accompanied with by-products during pyrolysis. During synthesis it should be ensured whether the intermediate gaseous products are toxic. Some of them may be utilized as carbon precursors for CNMs synthesis, while the rests should be given suitable post-treatments before liberation. The discussed reports in this article suggested that studying the pyrolysis and intermediate chemical reaction are highly important. In spite of using wastes as raw materials, the majority of reactions involve high temperature synthesis, such as CVD, which is considered as an energy consuming method. However, it cannot be dined that products obtained from high temperature methods have relatively better quality. CNMs obviously possess excellent properties which are valuable for many applications. However, the negative effects associated with CNMs cannot be overlooked due to their nm-ranged dimensions. The residues left during synthesis of CNMs can create environmental problems. Hence, rigorous protections should be executed in the process of developing methods to prepare CNMs.

metadata.abstractText: Carbon-based nanomaterials (CNMs) such as graphene and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have huge potential in environment and energy related applications. Although a wide range of synthesis methods has been developed to produce CNMs, green synthesis methods with either energy-saving reactions or inexpensive starting materials are gaining more attentions recently. It is evident from recent developments that converting low-valued waste materials into high-valued CNMs contributes towards sustainable materials processing and recycle technology. Objective of this review is to analyze green synthesis routes to prepare CNMs focusing on graphene and CNTs. This review starts with the identification of wastes that can be used as resources for producing CNMs followed by discussing various methods of CNTs and graphene synthesis. Finally, a summary of current status and future prospects of green synthesis methods are discussed.
